title: Why shopping on social media is booming
text:
"It's becoming more complex but unfortunately in a highly competitive retail market, where they're chasing consumer demand and retail is relatively flat, it's imperative that retailers keep up with the change," said PayPal Australia managing director Libby Roy.

"What the research shows is it's a trend that's building - the numbers shopping on social commerce are now five times what it was two years ago, so it's definitely a trend you can't ignore.

"Retail-tainment is a real thing and people do browse for fun. They do, however, make impulse purchases when they are browsing for fun on social media.

The numbers shopping on social commerce are now five times what it was two years ago, so it's definitely a trend you can't ignore. — Libby Roy, PayPal Australia

"But there's work to do to make it frictionless,'' she added, citing figures showing 37 per cent of consumers worry about sharing personal information on social media, and 22 per cent of businesses worry about the security of customer information.

"Consumers are still looking for safety and security ... so there's work to be done with secure payment mechanisms so consumers feel safe."

Younger generations are leading the charge on social commerce, reflecting the amount of time they spend uploading selfies and scrolling through posts.

About 38 per cent of Generation Z and 36 per cent of Millennials are buying through social media, compared with only 20 per cent of baby boomers, spending an average $121 a month.

Advertisement

Facebook is by far the most popular for social commerce, with 83 per cent of social shoppers transacting on the platform, followed by Instagram (34 per cent v 25 per cent in 2018 ) and Pinterest and Snapchat (12 per cent each).

While mobile commerce users spend more paying bills and utilities (62 per cent) than shopping for clothes and accessories (53 per cent), the reverse is true on social channels, with clothing and accessories, health and beauty and home and garden categories the most popular categories.

Businesses that engage in social commerce say that about 38 per cent of sales are now through this channel, while about 33 per cent of online sales are through mobile.

Online homewares retailer Temple & Webster, which has 560,00 social media followers, enables customers to shop through Instagram and chief executive Mark Coulter says it's exploring other social media markets.

"It's relatively small but what Instagram is great for is community engagement and brand building," he said.
description: Social shopping is booming but there's a gap between supply and demand, Paypal's latest mobile commerce report shows.
